newsitem.title: USA: INTERVIEW-Dreyfus, American to join the top 20.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW-Dreyfus, American to join the top 20.

text.p: The acquisition of American Exploration Co by Louis Dreyfus Natural Gas Corp in a $350 million stock and cash deal will create an oil and natural gas producer that ranks among the top 20 independents in terms of reserves.

The two companies also expect their share price improve as they will have a combined market capitalisation of more than $1.1 billion and will be better placed for further acquisitions, Mark Monroe, president of Dreyfus, and Mark Andrews, chief executive of American, said in an interview on Tuesday.
"We are going to be bigger and more powerful than either of our two companies would be on their own and better able to take advantage of any opportunities that arise," Monroe said.
The companies believe investors will also be forced to pay attention to a venture whose shares in issue will increase 150 percent to 18.5 million shares.
Louis Dreyfus, driven in the past by acquisitions, has spent $700 million recently in producing oil and gas properties.
"This really jump-starts our exploration programme, until now we primarily bought and developed wells," Monroe said.
Dreyfus will not have to borrow to finance the $45 million cash part of the acquisition, but has a $400 million credit facility of which $220-$230 million is currently in use.
The merged group will have a debt to equity ratio of 50 percent and debt of 2.3 earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortortisation, said American's Andrews.
Monroe said that the premium Dreyfus was paying for American's shares was around 20 percent over the three month average price.
Dreyfus, because of its concentration on buying in and developing reserves has a success rate of 95 percent in terms of gas wells developed to discovered.
"We see that solid growth and development success as providing the cashflow for American's exploration programme," said Andrews.
The production cost for Louis Dreyfus is 48 cents per thousand cubic feet of natural gas and somewhat higher for American because of its exploration programme.
"This is not a cash transaction, we are not borrowing $350 million to finance this, so if prices do turn down, we will be better placed to withstand any pressure because we are larger," said Monroe.
American expects to benefit from Louis Dreyfus natural gas marketing presence.
"If you can market your own gas, that really gives you an advantage," said Andrews. ((-- David Chance New York Newsroom 212 859 1902))
